title: co.combinatorics - Frobenius inner product of a zero line-sum matrix and a doubly stochastic matrix
body:
Let $A$ , $B$ be two $n	imes n$ real matrices. Let $A$ be a zero line-sum matrix where each row sum and each column sum equals zero, i.e., $$\sum_{i=1}^{n}a_{ij}=\sum_{j=1}^{n}a_{ij}=0 $$ (it seems there is no name for such matrix, see Name for matrices with vanishing row and column sums ). Let $B$ be a matrix where every entry is non-negative and each row sum and each column sum equals 1, i.e., $$\sum_{i=1}^{n}b_{ij}=\sum_{j=1}^{n}b_{ij}=1, b_{ij}\geq 0 $$ ( $B$ is a doubly stochastic matrix). An index set $S\subset[n]	imes[n]$ is a permutation set if $S$ has $n$ elements and if for every $(i,j),(i'j')\in S$ , $(i,j)
eq(i',j')$ then $i
eq i;$ and $j
eq j'$ . Now suppose there exists a permutation set $S$ such that $a_{ij}\geq 0$ for every $(i,j)\in S$ , $a_{ij}\leq 0$ for every $(i,j)
otin S$ and $\sum_{(i,j)\in S} b_{ij}\geq \sum_{(i,j)\in S'} b_{ij}$ for every permuation set $S'$ . Is it true that $\langle A,Bangle_F\geq 0$ ? Note this is obviously true if $B$ is a permutation matrix or if $b_{ij}=1/n$ for every $(i,j)$ . These seems like the two extreme cases. The Birkhoff polytope is the set of all doubly stochastic matrices (in fixed dimension). $\endgroup$ Jochen Glueck –  Jochen Glueck 2020-06-14 23:07:45 +00:00 Commented Jun 14, 2020 at 23:07 1 $ egingroup$ @JochenGlueck Thanks! I miswrote it because I was thinking about minimizing $\langle A,Bangle_F$ over a Birkhoff polytope. $\endgroup$ Lo Celso –  Lo Celso 2020-06-14 23:32:35 +00:00 Commented Jun 14, 2020 at 23:32 2 $ egingroup$ Going beyond your two examples, a computer might be of help finding potential counterexamples here. Data enters the problem in a very combinatorial way, and it's hard to get an intuition for why the statement should be true in general. So my 2 cents would be to try to finding some genuine counterexamples (e.g using a computer), and only in case of failure to find such, should you have more confidence in the claim, and try proving it. $\endgroup$ dohmatob –  dohmatob 2020-06-15 08:06:15 +00:00 Commented Jun 15, 2020 at 8:06 $ egingroup$ @dohmatob Thanks for your advice!
